page.title: 13Wild Mammals
page.content: The wild mammals found in the area are water voles and water shrews, which are declining in numbers and brown rats and mink which are increasing. There are plenty of foxes and roe deer and even badgers which do not normally like such a wet environment. The meadows are ideal for butterflies, the most common of which are marbled white (rare in most other parts of England), small copper, common blue, and orange tip. Dragonflies and damselflies find the rhynes to be most suitable breeding grounds, but there are fears that changes in rhyne management and water pollution from fertilisers and drainage pose threats to them. There are also many different species, including very rare ones, of water beetles, crickets and grasshoppers.
